elements.content: Two novel two-dimensional 3d–4f networks based on planar Co4Ln2 clusters supported by rigid 4′-(4-carboxyphenyl)-2,2′:6′,2″-terpyridine afford the first examples of high-dimensional networks with 3d–4f clusters behaving as single-molecule magnets.
elements.clean_text: Two novel two-dimensional 3d-4f networks based on planar Co4Ln2 clusters supported by rigid 4'-(4-carboxyphenyl)-2,2':6',2"-terpyridine afford the first examples of high-dimensional networks with 3d-4f clusters behaving as single-molecule magnets.

elements.content: Two novel two-dimensional 3d−4f networks based on planar Co4Ln2 clusters supported by rigid 4′-(4-carboxyphenyl)-2,2′:6′,2″-terpyridine afford the first examples of high-dimensional 3d−4f networks with hexanuclear planar clusters exhibiting single-molecule-magnet behavior.
elements.clean_text: Two novel two-dimensional 3d-4f networks based on planar Co4Ln2 clusters supported by rigid 4'-(4-carboxyphenyl)-2,2':6',2"-terpyridine afford the first examples of high-dimensional 3d-4f networks with hexanuclear planar clusters exhibiting single-molecule-magnet behavior.

elements.content: The discovery of the first [Mn12] cluster with slow paramagnetic relaxation stimulates the renaissance of molecular magnetism and initiates the emerging subject of single-molecule magnets (SMMs), which can be viewed as potential candidates for information storage devices, quantum computing, and spintronics devices. The SMMs feature the presence of energy barriers deriving from the combination of a large spin ground state (S) and a uniaxial Ising-like magnetoanistropy (D). In the past 2 decades, numerous complexes have been observed, and the most studied examples are based on 3d transition metals, especially MnIII ions. However, the magnetic relaxation blocking temperatures of 3d metal SMMs remain low. Hence, it is of great significance to pursue new SMMs with high blocking temperatures. Because of many 4f ions with strong magnetic anisotropy, especially for TbIII (7F6), DyIII (6H15/2), and HoIII (5H8), significant effort is devoted to constructing SMMs containing 3d–4f or pure 4f systems. Most of the reported lanthanide-based SMMs so far contain anisotropic DyIII ions, which can provide large spin and high spin–orbit coupling. In addition, compared with other 3d metal ions, the CoII ion in an octahedral environment has a large single-ion anisotropy afforded by spin–orbit coupling, which can also be a good candidate ion for SMMs, and then there are some Co-based SMMs reported in recent years. Therefore, the combination of CoII and LnIII ions in one system may be a new and interesting strategy to obtain novel SMMs. To our knowledge, the CoII–LnIII SMMs are very limited.
elements.clean_text: The discovery of the first [Mn12] cluster with slow paramagnetic relaxation stimulates the renaissance of molecular magnetism and initiates the emerging subject of single-molecule magnets (SMMs), which can be viewed as potential candidates for information storage devices, quantum computing, and spintronics devices. The SMMs feature the presence of energy barriers deriving from the combination of a large spin ground state (S) and a uniaxial Ising-like magnetoanistropy (D). In the past 2 decades, numerous complexes have been observed, and the most studied examples are based on 3d transition metals, especially MnIII ions. However, the magnetic relaxation blocking temperatures of 3d metal SMMs remain low. Hence, it is of great significance to pursue new SMMs with high blocking temperatures. Because of many 4f ions with strong magnetic anisotropy, especially for TbIII (7F6), DyIII (6H15/2), and HoIII (5H8), significant effort is devoted to constructing SMMs containing 3d-4f or pure 4f systems. Most of the reported lanthanide-based SMMs so far contain anisotropic DyIII ions, which can provide large spin and high spin-orbit coupling. In addition, compared with other 3d metal ions, the CoII ion in an octahedral environment has a large single-ion anisotropy afforded by spin-orbit coupling, which can also be a good candidate ion for SMMs, and then there are some Co-based SMMs reported in recent years. Therefore, the combination of CoII and LnIII ions in one system may be a new and interesting strategy to obtain novel SMMs. To our knowledge, the CoII-LnIII SMMs are very limited.

elements.content: Generally speaking, an SMM is an isolated molecule, and the intermolecular magnetic interactions are negligible. As a consequence, it is rather scarce that multidimensional networks exhibit SMM behaviors, and the metal-ion-embedded frameworks focused on d or f ions rather than d–f mixed ones. On the other hand, the organic ligands in SMMs play an important role in constructing metal clusters and separating each magnetic unit. 4′-(4-Carboxyphenyl)-2,2′:6′,2″-terpyridine (HL; Scheme ) follows the soft–hard concept that N and O donors fulfill the coordination affinities of 3d and 4f ions, respectively, so as to introduce 3d and 4f ions into one system. Furthermore, HL can separate metal clusters from each other, which fulfills the precondition of an isolated molecule for an SMM.
elements.clean_text: Generally speaking, an SMM is an isolated molecule, and the intermolecular magnetic interactions are negligible. As a consequence, it is rather scarce that multidimensional networks exhibit SMM behaviors, and the metal-ion-embedded frameworks focused on d or f ions rather than d-f mixed ones. On the other hand, the organic ligands in SMMs play an important role in constructing metal clusters and separating each magnetic unit. 4'-(4-Carboxyphenyl)-2,2':6',2"-terpyridine (HL; Scheme ) follows the soft-hard concept that N and O donors fulfill the coordination affinities of 3d and 4f ions, respectively, so as to introduce 3d and 4f ions into one system. Furthermore, HL can separate metal clusters from each other, which fulfills the precondition of an isolated molecule for an SMM.

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<caption>
<title>Representation of the Ligand HL</title>
</caption>
<graphic id="gr4" orientation="portrait" position="float" xlink:href="ic-2012-00372v_0003.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

Considering those aspects as above-mentioned, we use HL ligands to build Co–Ln complexs. Two novel two-dimensional (2D) Co–Ln networks constructed of rare planar hexanuclear Co4Ln2 clusters and L– anions were isolated, formulated as {[Co4Dy2(L)4(CO3)4(HCOO)2(H2O)2]·2DMF·5H2O} n (1; DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide) and {[Co4­Ho2­(L)4­(CO3)4­(HCOO)2­(H2O)2]·2DMF·2H2O} n (2) on the basis of crystal structure analyses. The magnetic study reveals that 1 exhibits slow magnetic relaxation. It may be noted that 1 is the first example of a high-dimensional 3d–4f framework containing heterometallic clusters that exhibits SMM behavior, although one example with a one-dimensional 3d–4f chain showing slow magnetic relaxation has been reported.
elements.clean_text: Considering those aspects as above-mentioned, we use HL ligands to build Co-Ln complexs. Two novel two-dimensional (2D) Co-Ln networks constructed of rare planar hexanuclear Co4Ln2 clusters and L- anions were isolated, formulated as {[Co4Dy2(L)4(CO3)4(HCOO)2(H2O)2]⋅2DMF⋅5H2O} n  (1; DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide) and {[Co4Ho2(L)4(CO3)4(HCOO)2(H2O)2]⋅2DMF⋅2H2O} n  (2) on the basis of crystal structure analyses. The magnetic study reveals that 1 exhibits slow magnetic relaxation. It may be noted that 1 is the first example of a high-dimensional 3d-4f framework containing heterometallic clusters that exhibits SMM behavior, although one example with a one-dimensional 3d-4f chain showing slow magnetic relaxation has been reported.

elements.content: 1 and 2 were successfully obtained by a one-pot reaction of HL, Co(CH3COO)2·4H2O, and Ln(NO3)3·6H2O (Ln = Dy, Ho) in a mixed DMF/H2O solution under solvothermal conditions (, SI), and the yields are 17% and 25% (based on Ln), respectively. Single-crystal X-ray analyses reveal that both 1 and 2 consist of a 2D network based on nearly planar hexanuclear Co4Ln2 clusters, lattice DMF, and H2O molecules for crystallization, and the difference between 1 and 2 is the number of lattice H2O molecules. Hence, 1 is chosen to depict the structure in detail. The hexanuclear Co4Dy2 cluster and its planar core are depicted in Figure a,b. The planar core of 1 contains a [Co4Dy2(CO3)4]6+ cluster with four CoII and two DyIII ions held together by four CO3 2– anions from decomposition of DMF. On the basis of bond valence sum (BVS) analyses of Co sites, the BVS of Co ions falls into the range from 1.868 to 1.968 (Table 3 in the ), confirming the 2+ oxidation state of Co ions in 1 and 2. Two CO3 2– in η2:η2:η2:μ4-bridging mode act as hexadentate ligands to chelate two CoII ions (Co1 and Co2) and two DyIII ions. Dy1 and Dy1a are double-bridged by two μ2-O atoms from two μ4-CO3 2– to form a Dy2O2 rhombus with angles of 110.54(33) and 69.46(29)° for Dy–O–Dy and O–Dy–O, respectively. The remaining two CO3 2– as tridentate ligands in η1:η2:μ2-bridging mode link Dy1 and Co1 at the edge of the core. Four CoII ions (Co1, Co2, Co1a, and Co2a) are precisely coplanar, while two DyIII ions (Dy1 and Dy1a) slightly deviate from the plane and lie above and below with deviations of 0.2885 Å. The eight-coordinated environment of Dy1 is completed by two L– anions and one H2O molecule, close to a distorted double-capped trigonal prism. The six-coordinated geometries of CoII ions are completed by three N atoms from L– anions and three O atoms from CO3 2– and/or formate anions, forming distorted octahedra. It should be stated that formate is the product of decomposition of DMF. In the core, the Dy···Dy and Co···Co distances are 3.930(1) and 4.125(3) Å, respectively, and those of Dy···Co are 4.003(6) (Dy1···Co1) and 4.501(6) Å (Dy1···Co2).
elements.clean_text: 1 and 2 were successfully obtained by a one-pot reaction of HL, Co(CH3COO)2⋅4H2O, and Ln(NO3)3⋅6H2O (Ln = Dy, Ho) in a mixed DMF/H2O solution under solvothermal conditions (, SI), and the yields are 17% and 25% (based on Ln), respectively. Single-crystal X-ray analyses reveal that both 1 and 2 consist of a 2D network based on nearly planar hexanuclear Co4Ln2 clusters, lattice DMF, and H2O molecules for crystallization, and the difference between 1 and 2 is the number of lattice H2O molecules. Hence, 1 is chosen to depict the structure in detail. The hexanuclear Co4Dy2 cluster and its planar core are depicted in Figure a,b. The planar core of 1 contains a [Co4Dy2(CO3)4]6+ cluster with four CoII and two DyIII ions held together by four CO3 2- anions from decomposition of DMF. On the basis of bond valence sum (BVS) analyses of Co sites, the BVS of Co ions falls into the range from 1.868 to 1.968 (Table 3 in the ), confirming the 2+ oxidation state of Co ions in 1 and 2. Two CO3 2- in η2:η2:η2:μ4-bridging mode act as hexadentate ligands to chelate two CoII ions (Co1 and Co2) and two DyIII ions. Dy1 and Dy1a are double-bridged by two μ2-O atoms from two μ4-CO3 2- to form a Dy2O2 rhombus with angles of 110.54(33) and 69.46(29)° for Dy-O-Dy and O-Dy-O, respectively. The remaining two CO3 2- as tridentate ligands in η1:η2:μ2-bridging mode link Dy1 and Co1 at the edge of the core. Four CoII ions (Co1, Co2, Co1a, and Co2a) are precisely coplanar, while two DyIII ions (Dy1 and Dy1a) slightly deviate from the plane and lie above and below with deviations of 0.2885 Å. The eight-coordinated environment of Dy1 is completed by two L- anions and one H2O molecule, close to a distorted double-capped trigonal prism. The six-coordinated geometries of CoII ions are completed by three N atoms from L- anions and three O atoms from CO3 2- and/or formate anions, forming distorted octahedra. It should be stated that formate is the product of decomposition of DMF. In the core, the Dy⋅⋅⋅Dy and Co⋅⋅⋅Co distances are 3.930(1) and 4.125(3) Å, respectively, and those of Dy⋅⋅⋅Co are 4.003(6) (Dy1⋅⋅⋅Co1) and 4.501(6) Å (Dy1⋅⋅⋅Co2).

elements.content: Hexanuclear Co4Dy2 cluster (a), its planar core (b), and the 2D network (c) of 1. H atoms are omitted for clarity. Color code: green polyhedra, [DyO8]; purple polyhedra, [CoN3O3].
elements.clean_text: 1  Hexanuclear Co4Dy2 cluster (a), its planar core (b), and the 2D network (c) of 1. H atoms are omitted for clarity. Color code: green polyhedra, [DyO8]; purple polyhedra, [CoN3O3].

elements.content: Each hexanuclear Co4Dy2 cluster is encapsulated by eight L– ligands, as shown in Figure a. Each CoII ion in the cluster coordinates to three N atoms from one L–, while the DyIII ion is coordinated with one monodentate and one bidentate carboxyl groups from two L– above and below the planar core, indicating two coordination modes of L–: tetradentate and pentadentate. Both of them bridge two metal ions (Dy1, Co1 and Dy1, Co2, respectively). Finally, L– ligands use their chemical characteristics of N and O atoms to fulfill the affinities of CoII and DyIII ions and connect those clusters to form a 2D network (Figure c). Considering Co4Dy2 as a four-connected node, the topology can be analyzed as a 2D 44-net with a distance of 17.669 Å between nodes (Figure S1 in the ). The 2D motifs are stacking along the c direction in a staggered −AB– mode (Figure S2 in the ).
elements.clean_text: Each hexanuclear Co4Dy2 cluster is encapsulated by eight L- ligands, as shown in Figure a. Each CoII ion in the cluster coordinates to three N atoms from one L-, while the DyIII ion is coordinated with one monodentate and one bidentate carboxyl groups from two L- above and below the planar core, indicating two coordination modes of L-: tetradentate and pentadentate. Both of them bridge two metal ions (Dy1, Co1 and Dy1, Co2, respectively). Finally, L- ligands use their chemical characteristics of N and O atoms to fulfill the affinities of CoII and DyIII ions and connect those clusters to form a 2D network (Figure c). Considering Co4Dy2 as a four-connected node, the topology can be analyzed as a 2D 44-net with a distance of 17.669 Å between nodes (Figure S1 in the ). The 2D motifs are stacking along the c direction in a staggered -AB- mode (Figure S2 in the ).

elements.content: The calculated and experimental powder X-ray diffraction patterns were compared in Figure S3 in the , and the results confirm the purity of 1 and 2. The direct-current (dc) magnetic properties of 1 and 2 were investigated under a 1 kOe field in the temperature range 2–300 K, and plots of χM T vs T are depicted (Figure S4 in the ). The χM T values at 300 K of 42.30 and 40.26 cm3 K mol–1 for 1 and 2, respectively, are more than the those expected for four spin-only CoII ions (S = 3/2) and two LnIII ions in the ground state. As reported in many of the CoII-containing compounds, the room temperature χM T value is usually higher than the expected spin-only one as a result of the orbital contribution of the high-spin CoII ions in the octahedra to the magnetism. With decreasing temperature, the χM T value gradually decreases until 50 K and then drops sharply to reach minimum values of 11.23 and 7.80 cm3 K mol–1 at 2.0 K for 1 and 2, respectively. Thermal evolution of the χM T value observed suggests antiferromagnetic behavior; however, it is difficult to depict the interactions of Co–Co, Co–Ln, and Ln–Ln in 1 and 2 because both CoII and LnIII ions have intrinsically complicated magnetic characteristics (including the presence of spin–orbit coupling and magnetic anisotropy). The field dependences of magnetization data for 1 and 2 have been measured at 2, 3, and 5 K (Figures , S5 in the ). At 2 K, the magnetization of 1 and 2 quickly increases with enhancement of the field below 1 T. From 1 to 5 T, the value of 1 slowly rises similarly to that of reported [DyCo] systems and then linearly increases above 5 T, which may be the peculiarity of the powder magnetization reported in Powell’s work. The lack of magnetic saturation even at 8 T and the nonsuperposition of M vs H/T plots (Figure ) indicate the presence of magnetic anisotropy and/or low-lying excited states.
elements.clean_text: The calculated and experimental powder X-ray diffraction patterns were compared in Figure S3 in the , and the results confirm the purity of 1 and 2. The direct-current (dc) magnetic properties of 1 and 2 were investigated under a 1 kOe field in the temperature range 2-300 K, and plots of χM T vs T are depicted (Figure S4 in the ). The χM T values at 300 K of 42.30 and 40.26 cm3 K mol-1 for 1 and 2, respectively, are more than the those expected for four spin-only CoII ions (S = 3/2) and two LnIII ions in the ground state. As reported in many of the CoII-containing compounds, the room temperature χM T value is usually higher than the expected spin-only one as a result of the orbital contribution of the high-spin CoII ions in the octahedra to the magnetism. With decreasing temperature, the χM T value gradually decreases until 50 K and then drops sharply to reach minimum values of 11.23 and 7.80 cm3 K mol-1 at 2.0 K for 1 and 2, respectively. Thermal evolution of the χM T value observed suggests antiferromagnetic behavior; however, it is difficult to depict the interactions of Co-Co, Co-Ln, and Ln-Ln in 1 and 2 because both CoII and LnIII ions have intrinsically complicated magnetic characteristics (including the presence of spin-orbit coupling and magnetic anisotropy). The field dependences of magnetization data for 1 and 2 have been measured at 2, 3, and 5 K (Figures , S5 in the ). At 2 K, the magnetization of 1 and 2 quickly increases with enhancement of the field below 1 T. From 1 to 5 T, the value of 1 slowly rises similarly to that of reported [DyCo] systems and then linearly increases above 5 T, which may be the peculiarity of the powder magnetization reported in Powell's work. The lack of magnetic saturation even at 8 T and the nonsuperposition of M vs H/T plots (Figure ) indicate the presence of magnetic anisotropy and/or low-lying excited states.

elements.content: M vs H/T plots at different temperatures below 5 K for 1 and 2 (inset).
elements.clean_text: 2   M vs H/T plots at different temperatures below 5 K for 1 and 2 (inset).

elements.content: L– ligands in 1 and 2 link Co4Ln2 clusters and effectively separate these clusters from each other, as well as the presence of significant magnetic anisotropy and unpaired electrons in those Co–Ln systems; as a result, both 1 and 2 may exhibit interesting magnetic behavior. In order to probe any SMM behavior, ac magnetic susceptibilities were performed for 1 and 2 in the temperature range 2–20 K with zero dc field, and frequency-dependent out-of-phase signals for 1 were observed, meaning that 1 has an Ising-type anisotropy, but the maximum of χ″ is lower than 2 K (Figure S6 in the ). Comparably, out-of-phase susceptibility for 2 is negligible (Figure S7 in the ). The behavior of 1 indicates the presence of slow magnetization relaxation, but the relaxation time and energy barrier cannot be deduced from these data because of the restriction of the instruments without full peak observed above 2.0 K. This phenomenon may originate from the presence of quantum tunneling of magnetization (QTM), and QTM may be suppressed by applying a static dc field. Therefore, the frequency dependence of ac susceptibility was obtained under a static dc field of 5000 Oe for 1. As expected, QTM is partially suppressed, and the maxima of the χ″ values were shifted to higher temperature above 2.0 K and detected for frequencies higher than 3111 Hz for 1 (Figure ). The relaxation time was extracted from the temperature of the maximum χ″(ω) as τ(T max) = ω–1, and the magnetization relaxation time (τ) follows the Arrhenius law, τ = τ0 exp(E a/k B T). The solid line in Figure (inset) shows the result of a least-squares fit of the ac susceptibility relaxation data between 3111 and 9111 Hz to the Arrhenius equation, giving an energy gap (E a/k B) of 7.6 K and a preexponential factor τ0 = 1.9 × 10–6 s for 1.
elements.clean_text: L- ligands in 1 and 2 link Co4Ln2 clusters and effectively separate these clusters from each other, as well as the presence of significant magnetic anisotropy and unpaired electrons in those Co-Ln systems; as a result, both 1 and 2 may exhibit interesting magnetic behavior. In order to probe any SMM behavior, ac magnetic susceptibilities were performed for 1 and 2 in the temperature range 2-20 K with zero dc field, and frequency-dependent out-of-phase signals for 1 were observed, meaning that 1 has an Ising-type anisotropy, but the maximum of χ" is lower than 2 K (Figure S6 in the ). Comparably, out-of-phase susceptibility for 2 is negligible (Figure S7 in the ). The behavior of 1 indicates the presence of slow magnetization relaxation, but the relaxation time and energy barrier cannot be deduced from these data because of the restriction of the instruments without full peak observed above 2.0 K. This phenomenon may originate from the presence of quantum tunneling of magnetization (QTM), and QTM may be suppressed by applying a static dc field. Therefore, the frequency dependence of ac susceptibility was obtained under a static dc field of 5000 Oe for 1. As expected, QTM is partially suppressed, and the maxima of the χ" values were shifted to higher temperature above 2.0 K and detected for frequencies higher than 3111 Hz for 1 (Figure ). The relaxation time was extracted from the temperature of the maximum χ"(ω) as τ(T max) = ω-1, and the magnetization relaxation time (τ) follows the Arrhenius law, τ = τ0 exp(E a/k B T). The solid line in Figure  (inset) shows the result of a least-squares fit of the ac susceptibility relaxation data between 3111 and 9111 Hz to the Arrhenius equation, giving an energy gap (E a/k B) of 7.6 K and a preexponential factor τ0 = 1.9 × 10-6 s for 1.

elements.content: The obtained parameters are in the region of some reported DyIII SMMs (the lowest-energy barrier reported is 6.2 K) and confirm the SMM behavior of 2D complex 1. The magnetic slow relaxation behavior of Co4Dy2 complex 1 cannot be clearly concluded because of the nature of the CoII and DyIII ions; however, because no out-of-phase signals were observed for Co4Ho2 analogues, the SMM behavior of 1 may mainly be associated with the anisotropic DyIII ions.
elements.clean_text: The obtained parameters are in the region of some reported DyIII SMMs (the lowest-energy barrier reported is 6.2 K) and confirm the SMM behavior of 2D complex 1. The magnetic slow relaxation behavior of Co4Dy2 complex 1 cannot be clearly concluded because of the nature of the CoII and DyIII ions; however, because no out-of-phase signals were observed for Co4Ho2 analogues, the SMM behavior of 1 may mainly be associated with the anisotropic DyIII ions.

elements.content: Temperature dependence of ac susceptibilities under a dc field of 5 kOe for 1. Inset: Arrhenius plot for 1 using the ac data at frequencies of 3111–9111 Hz.
elements.clean_text: 3  Temperature dependence of ac susceptibilities under a dc field of 5 kOe for 1. Inset: Arrhenius plot for 1 using the ac data at frequencies of 3111-9111 Hz.

elements.content: In summary, two CoII–LnIII coordination polymers (1 and 2) have been produced using a rigid HL ligand under solvothermal conditions, exhibiting novel 2D networks built from planar Co4Ln2 clusters. Compound 1 exhibits slow relaxation of magnetization, indicating SMM behavior. It is the first time that a 2D 3d–4f heterometallic coordination polymer exhibits SMM behavior. The results presented herein indicate that the construction of multidimensional networks with metal clusters is a feasible approach to preparing novel magnetic materials and will broaden the field of SMMs.
elements.clean_text: In summary, two CoII-LnIII coordination polymers (1 and 2) have been produced using a rigid HL ligand under solvothermal conditions, exhibiting novel 2D networks built from planar Co4Ln2 clusters. Compound 1 exhibits slow relaxation of magnetization, indicating SMM behavior. It is the first time that a 2D 3d-4f heterometallic coordination polymer exhibits SMM behavior. The results presented herein indicate that the construction of multidimensional networks with metal clusters is a feasible approach to preparing novel magnetic materials and will broaden the field of SMMs.

metadata.title:
Two-Dimensional 3d–4f
Networks Containing Planar Co4Ln2 Clusters with
Single-Molecule-Magnet Behaviors
